text1: Several heavy thrusters that slowly recharge off a small auxiliary reactor, granting a quick boost of agility and speed.
text3: Grants a brief boost to speed and agility.

text1: Drone manufactories of the Resolute can instantly re-deploy all destroyed drones, plus field three additional drones, for a short time. Can exhaust supply with repeated power surges.
text3: Redeploy all drones, plus an additional drone per each bay, for a small flux and replacement rate cost.

text1:
The Colubris is a trans-atmospheric frigate packed with late-Domain technologies and a high-specification reactor. Mount flexibility ensures that this frigate--though expensive to maintain and deploy--is never out of place in any fleet. It is unfortunately also among the most fragile of frigates due to a lack of "empty" space and limited redundancies.

Despite its description mentioning "trans-atmospheric", the Colubris must undergo a brief period of preparation to engage in atmospheric flight. This process requires most weapon emplacements be retracted into airtight bulkheads to reduce air friction, leaving the ship with just two point defense mounts.  Still, it is generally favored by Star Federation diplomatic officials, serving as both the security of a warship and a symbol of pride conduct business from.

Taking advantage of the unstable nature of hyperspace, the core of the ship is uniquely capable of creating a microfracture around the entire ship. Though vulnerable while "charging", this quick FTL jump provides more distance than a traditional phasic "skip" and its high technological requirements.
text3: Jumps to nearby location, but lowers shield and becomes vulnerable for a brief time.

text1: A backup battery supercharges all engines and weapons for a short period of time. Increases ship speed and weapon refire rates 150%, and reduces weapon flux cost by 50%.
text3: Gain a sharply decaying boost of agility, speed, rate of fire, and reduction weapon flux cost.

text1: A backup battery supercharges all engines and weapons for a short period of time. Increases ship speed and weapon refire rates 150%, and reduces weapon flux cost by 50%.
text3: Gain a sharply decaying boost of agility, speed, rate of fire, and reduction weapon flux cost.

text1: Additional fuel injectors increase thrust and engine response times dramatically, but prevent any braking effects while active.
text3: Boosts engine performance for a short period, but prevents everything but forward movement.

text1:
The Super Buffalo is a native Star Federation improvement on the typical Load-n-Pray Buffalo freighter. Modern minimum defense specifications complement extra crew amenities like SonicShowers, automated point defense AIs, and noise-isolated berthing slots. Other improvements come at a higher maintenance cost and do not grant the ship any significant benefits outside of the engine system. While boosters give the Super Buffalo a higher chance to escape hostile forces, it would be unwise to expect a flawless survival rate.

The Super Buffalo's business prospects are admittedly rather bleak, as the number of potential buyers capable of affording it is surprisingly small due to the tense factional politics of the Star Federation and the increasing competence of pirates. Corporate trading managers often opt for the standard Buffalo instead, as it offers higher marginal profits and when shadowed by for patrols in core-system lanes. Despite this, the ergonomics of the Super Buffalo means it has a greater chance of appearing in the protective formations of scavenger and privateer fleets.

A mysterious mix of Star Federation refinement and "low tech" technology, the Nisos clearly a Star Federation Osprey converted to provide ballistic fire support. Its forward firepower appears to exceed or match that of the heaviest cruisers in existence, nevermind the presence is enhanced by numerous energy conduits encircling the ship. Several locations on the vessel appear have missing components and abruptly-ending network lines, suggesting there was some kind of informational relay planned at each point.

What little coule be extracted from ship's data logs gave repeated mentions of a clandestine organization known as Section 23. In contradcition to the public knowledge of the Star Federation and its various internal factions, this organization doesn't seem to exist. From what you can gather, Section 23 was--or is--a breakaway group that has gone to great lengths to conceal its existence, with relevant constructional data suggesting that significant resources and materials were diverted to its cause during the chaos of the AI Wars. Clearly, there is much more to learn about Section 23 and its goals.

At least for now, you believe it is an isolated discovery.

A ship-length, front-mounted "scrap" cannon that fires an expanding cloud of projectiles at extended ranges. While individually weak and therefore less effective against armor, the sum damage of projectiles can overwhelm shield generators.

The specially-designed projectiles of Scrapshot weapons collapse inwards on themselves on impact, fusing their cores in a millionth of a second. The resulting micro-fusion bursts cause equal damage across all types of defense and produce electromagnetic effects that potentially disrupt weaker components. The only drawback of the artillery variant is the considerably longer capacitor charge time, but range and damage are noticeably increased.

The Hirondelle is a omni-purpose trans-atmospheric shuttle with the ability to launch ground assaults, and represents a bold Federation reimagination of the popular Kite shuttle. While it boasts impressive offensive capabilities with its spaceborne weapon package, the small size of the vessel makes it ill-suited for space combat. Despite this drawback, fleet logisticians intoxicated by cost-effectiveness reports tend to embrace the Hirondelle, clearly having never set foot on one headed into the thick of battle.

Dubbed the "Dodo" by its spacer crew, the Hirondelle is indeed quite large and ungainly for a trans-atmospheric ship. This is largely due to the space required for its trooper complement, whose cramped and spartan living quarters can accommodate nearly a hundred (unhappy) marines and their suits. Most of them are situated in the midsection underbelly, located unnervingly close to the bombs bays meant to soften up prospective targets. It's no surprise the troopers call the ship the "Doodoo" instead, but with varying degrees of language severity.

A technologically advanced hull, the Emerillon defies its destroyer classification with superior maneuverability and firepower. Built around a one-of-a-kind rotary cannon, the ridiculous performance of its main weapon allows it to chip away at toughest defenses and thickest fighter screens. A perfect ship for ambitious Star Federation officers looking for career-advancing glories, but exceedingly rare due to construction costs.

Built during the peak of Star Federation design capability, the lack of widespread ergonomics indicates part of its design was assisted by an AI. It could also have been the work of an overworked weapon-system architect doubly-assigned to the design of the crew accommodations. The Emerillon also lacks standardized parts, much to the irritation of maintenance crew, which is odd considering the design archetypes it shares with many Star Federation ships.

Of course, an even more advanced blueprint is rumored to be floating around on the Dark Holonet. It is possible that an Emerillon blueprint was smuggled off the NavArch campus by an engineer, likely after some fallout between different weapon divisions competing for funding. Though only one version ever made it to mass production, the ghost of its missing competition remains an undying whisper.

A powerful rotary gun designed to shred and destroy medium-to-light targets, the Repressor's flux costs are kept reasonable by the incredible amount of support equipment built into Emerillon. Few weapons in the sector can match its terrible assault, especially when its mothership engages its Redline ship system. It is estimated to cost about 400,000 centi-credits every twelve minutes of operation.

Amazingly, the entire Repressor complex is largely automated by Delta-class AI systems, right down to hyper-cooling arrays, recoil dampers, and fire control systems. Perhaps, in light of this autonomy, auxiliary systems such as life support and berthing are pushed to the side pontoons of the craft. Such isolation does leave plenty of space in the main hull for customization, even if it does result in less radiation protection for the crew.

An elusive "modified" version of the already rare base model, the Magnellion is faster and more dangerous than its ballsistic counterpart. Despite having roughly the same combat premise, it offers a radically different main armament in the form of a rotary plasma pulser. Doubled conduits and internal reconfiguration brings minor improvements to the engines and shields over its ballistic counterpart - no doubt a work of some ingenious underworld chiphacker.

Though the Emerillon's main weapon was always planned to be interchangeable, the effort never panned out. A large reason was Domain suppression campaigns putting pressure on the Star Federation, triggering a shift of budgets towards production instead of design. An extra reactor replaces the autofactory complex in the Magnellion, but the power is almost entirely consumed by the main gun. Much like its cousin, the true potential of this raider could possibly be found in the disengaging of its saftey interlocks.

A rapid-fire energy cannon with excellent generalist utility, but suffers accuracy loss during prolonged firing. Affectionately titled "Spinthrasher" by the underworld chiphackers in possession of the original blueprint.

The Spinthrasher utilizes a form of laser ignition system to superheat special reaction pellets. Uneven combustion on one side of the pellet creates a directional explosion that fires the fusion pellet out with significant velocity. The laser assembly itself is kept safe with powerful magnetic containment fields, and the weapon utilizes multiple supercooled barrels to manage the heat from residual plasma.
A largely inconspicuous variant of the Swarm Battery missile system which trades modularity for high-quality ammoforges.

Notwithstanding irony of an anti-pirate vessel falling into pirate hands, this flying disregard-for-safety was custom-crafted by its pirate crew for extreme speed and lethality. A well-to-do pirate boss haphazardly ordered secondary reactors behind bulkheads, simplified missile mounts, and probably ignored the immense cost of permanently overdriving the ship's entire system. But somehow, it worked.

A heavily armed and armored destroyer designed to pose a threat to cruisers, the Cormorant wields supercharged ballistic mounts and ungainly missile capacity for its tonnage. Upon expending its missiles, the lack of follow-through or initiation may leave it somewhat passive for a heavy destroyer.

Created to oppose rickety pirate gun-barges common in with wilder ages of the Persean Arm, this old model destroyer follows a practical and simplistic doctrine: Missiles are limited, but so are enemy reinforcements. The success of this philosophy has allowed the simple Cormorant to persevere in Federation doctrine throughout the many cycles.

The vaguely organic flow of the Stormwalker's hull gives no reasonable answer to the problems it poses: How does a vessel this large enter p-space without a proper phase-coil array? Even ignoring the impossible question, the craft never seems to dive as deep as normal phasecraft might. Sensors also reveal a phase density unnatural for the ship's real size, as well as temporal fluidity that eminates from strange crystalline arrays dispersed throughout in the hull. The vessel is otherwise standard for a Federation-pattern hull, except for an array of shock-pylons that effortlessly disable nearby threats.

The crystals appear to be a kind of temporal resonance generators, a concept once thought exclusive to ultra-rare prototype Tri-Tachyon hulls. Bathing the hull in the ethereal glow of temporal disassociation, powering these assemblies collapses them into non-euclidian constructs which pulls the ship into a chronal paradox, even surpassing the dilation inherent to phase drives in short bursts. Being borne of two greatest Domain ultratechs, this "Stormwalker" would certainly condemned by Luddic sects across the sector as a fruit from Moloch's tree. After all, this vessel was surely reft from the minds of unfathomably intelligent AI cores, assuming such artefact were able to exist outside of the Domain's clutches.

Phase ships are rumored to be psychologically disturbing places for their crew and officers. This is also true of the Stormwalker, whose entire hull seems to produce unqiuely "aural" stress sounds when its phase filaments glow hot with flux. Such behavior is inconsistent with the limited research data available Domain pattern dimensional coils, and

Thickly armored by Star Federation standards, the Shivan is highly reminiscent of "low tech" era ships. The Shivan's defining novelty is a micro-missile replicator that replenishes smaller missiles - at least while supplies last. It is one of the least unique among lost vessels found in fringe sectors, but perhaps that which is most familiar can also be the most useful.

Though the true story of this hull may be forever lost, evidence of the Federation's legacy remains on-board. Specifically, "warp" jump-drives once promised mid-range intergalactic traversal without the need for gates. Jump beacons connected Federation systems and provided convienient access to their overspecialized industrial bases, much to the ire of Domain planners. Unfortunately, with the Collapse, the light of the Jump Beacons was also snuffed out, and any jump-drive ships in transit were scattershot across the far stars Persean region. Much of them are purportedly like the Shivan's design, though a few other patterns have been discovered across the cycles. 

Holonet speculation is intriguiging: Perhaps some sort of mass retreat of the Shivan's creators was in order? Few ship examples exist in the public space, and their computers are unhelpfully fried from lightyears of dissonant hyperwarp. The Octavian Federal High Command has never been particularly talkative about the Collapse, much preferring to look to the future. Some more questionable claims suggest there is a datavault on pre-Collapse activities in the Command Spire, still sealed to this day.

A mysterious jellyfish-like frigate marked by a unique phase-displacement and oversized weapons package. Though the craft's single phase coil is undersized for the displacement, several phase-resonant filaments seem to bind the hull a curious area of positively-charged p-space. The rest of frigate largely conforms to the Star Federation's mundane standards, save for a curious pair of shock vanes providing point defense coverage.

Quite a cramped ship that presents itself like the inside of a creatures' ribcage, the Polyp has a disturbing lack of access points for critical life support systems. While being unable to directly interact with essential equipemnt like air cyclers suggests an impossible level of design oversight, a compliment of slug-like repair drones quickly attends to minor ship damage by excreting a rapidly-hardening smart repair gel.
Fires a large number of flak canisters with variable-timed proximity fuses all around the ship. More charges, but a lower reloading rate.
text3: Fires a large number of flak canisters with variable-timed proximity fuses all around the ship. Each canister deals 200 High Explosive damage in an area and is targeted to avoid friendly fire. The light version is slower to cycle and replenish charges.

text1: Gradually doubles weapon fire rate and engine power. System termination or ship overload produces an explosion of energy projectiles and a short overload, each scaling up depending on the ship's flux level.
text3: Slowly doubles weapon fire rate and engine power, followed by an explosion of energy and short overload. Both scale higher depending on the ship's flux level.

text1: The immense flux core of the Rebellion is uniquely suited to dumping overload energy into space. The wavefront is incredibly destructive at close range and is laden with enough ionic energy to disrupt an entire fleet. While friendly ships can polarize themselves for immunity, any nearby enemies or neutral entities will be affected.

A Rebellion given a hostile coat of orange paint and glimmering neon-teal lines, this battleship is a modification of the Rebellion used by seditious Federation worlds siding with the Hegemony during the Second AI war. Though the war ended with the signing of the treaty, and these rebellious worlds collapsed without support, the havoc these distinctive vessels caused undoubtably left Scaria the only unruined Federation world. Like most traitor assets, these models were captured, evaluated, and then disposed of by letting them fall into crushing depths of a gas giant.

Opponents are quick to see how the powerful energy weapon grid has been exchanged for numerous ammunition bunkers and ammo-feed lines. This brutal vessel is much more potent at standoff ranges than the mainline version, though at a marginal cost to its shield and flux systems. It is also somewhat more intensive to maintain, given the amount of ammunition required to fire so many gun batteries.

Developed quite near the Collapse, the templates of this siege vessel bear the distinctive work of an AI architect. Difficult to service junctions, a lack of internal access points, blackbox technologies, and a central hab-zone crossed by more coolant lines and data-processing terminals than usual. This vessel could likely have been entirely automated with just a few more years of development. Surely, though, that would be an incredibly bad idea.
Increases fighter wing speed by 30% and increases fire rate for the carrier. Generates a moderate amount of flux.

A fairly unimpressive anti-armor beam at a glance, the Hull Beam produces powerful "particle spall" explosions that ruin exposed hull.

Theoretical physicists imagine the effects of these "hull beams" originate from a quantum pairing effect between virtual particles in our spacetime and those of the infamous P-space dimension. The rapid oscillation of each other's phases between dimensions destabilizes, managing to produce twice the destructive effect when the particle stream is interrupted by a physical object. The charged nature of intruding particles means it is attracted to physical components, producing little hyperspace distortions that violently ionize pockets of gas. The result is devastating against pressurized bulkheads left uncovered by armor or shielding.

Initially created through Koralia Advanced Energy's Civilian Applications initiative, the Hullbeam series were developed after corporate executives observed the powerful fragmentation effects on starship hull by the simplistic Microbeam crystal. It was thought that a more mature crystal, perhaps with unstable qualities, could produce the same effect on non-energetic targets like asteroids. This was unfortunately not true, and the lethargic particle stream seemed underwhelming despite its more pronounced effects against armor panels. It wasn't even imagined that the partner beam's destabilization would create interdimensional fractures, thereby saving the concept with a brand new prototype weapon budget.

Though not an outstanding weapon if solely judged by the hard-number specifications, the secondary cavitation and explosive effects produced by this beam can rupture exposed hull to a fatal degree.

Theoretical physicists imagine the effects of these "hull beams" originate from a quantum pairing effect between virtual particles in our spacetime and those of the infamous P-space dimension. The rapid oscillation of each other's phases between dimensions destabilizes, managing to produce twice the destructive effect when the particle stream is interrupted by a physical object. The charged nature of intruding particles means it is attracted to physical components, producing little hyperspace distortions that violently ionize pockets of gas. The result is devastating against pressurized bulkheads left uncovered by armor or shielding.

Lacking the ability to perhaps "study" these virtual P-space, particle weapon engineers can only observe how the crystal assembly seems to be slightly phased at one end. Likely a consequence of the time spent extruding the crystal in its zero-G forge, the maturity of the phased lattice means it usually starts to sprout physical growths. These are filed off through physical abrasion, for the same explosive effects produced by the beam can occur when using a high-powered cutting beam.

The long accelerator rail and upscaled capacitors of the Pike allow it to pressure targets from afar. Somewhat underpowered versus shields and armor, but ideal for support vessels and light craft.

Essentially the same "caliber" as the Microbeam, the Pike's introduction came relatively quickly as Federation weapon design institutions struggled with new lens refinement and energy pump mechanisms. Though the ungainly particle chute greatly accelerated the stream, the effect of the beam impact remained oddly unchanged.

Licensed and built by Koralia Advanced Energy after the Collapse, the infamously long silhouette of the Pike seems to amuse the crew of the ships wielding it. Much less so to the officers and crew - for the constant jokes about "compensating" for something grow tiresome quickly. Crew rotation through Pikebeam ops teams are approximately double or triple that of other weapons, so the saying goes.

A snub-nosed exotic particle beam with good range and punch. Nearly useless versus shields, but produces a destructive spalling effect on bare hull. 

Powered by a mysterious crystal substrate, the base-emitter of the Microbeam is grown from a fragment of crystal sample distributed across several forge facilities. Each beam shard is grown in conditions that could only be described as a "stellar nursery", an extremely hot but somewhat low-pressure atomic soup pulsed by radiation. Most crystals come out malformed, but a few can be extracted, milled down, and eventually fitted to the frame of a weapon.

A simple discharge can be achieved by cryogenically cooling the medium until it starts bleeding excess energy. The larger the core is, the longer it takes to discharge - but all produce a stream of exotic, unstable, and even virtual particles. Such short-lived and enigmatic things were seemingly difficult to study even before the Collapse, nevermind in the state of the post-Collapse conditions.

An advanced launcher that fires devastating flux-charged torpedoes. The weapon features an internal autoforge because the torpedo lacks a traditional warhead, and while is capable of indefinite combat operation, the ready-rack capacity is unusually shallow.

The Dace MRM excels at general-purpose destruction of unshielded targets. Reloading and charging takes longer than more simple launchers, but the initial speed boost is crucial to delivering the heavier missile on target.

The Mooneye MRM is a phase-resonant missile designed to disrupt shields as it disintegrates within them. This advanced launcher features a powered launch rail which greatly increases its chance to hit distant targets.

A triple-assembly launcher for the Mooneye MRM, good for pressuring shields and harassing lightly armored targets. Features the ability to replenish its ammunition stores thanks to the mostly inert design of its warheads.
Increases missile projectile speed and missile weapon reload rate. Also gives a smaller performance boost to engine power and ballistic weapon fire rate.
text3: Increases missile projectile speed and missile weapon reload rate. Also slightly boosts engine power and ballistc weapon fire rate.
